snippet: Advocates say a “no” vote on the treaty could hurt Ireland’s ability to borrow internationally, while opponents say the pact’s limits on deficits and debt could prolong Ireland’s slump.
abstract: Irish voters are skeptical as referendum approaches on a new European financial treaty intended to ensure stability and sustain the country's ability to borrow internationally; critics of the treaty argue that its limits on deficits and debt could prolong Ireland's economic slump.
lead_paragraph: Advocates say a “no” vote on the treaty could hurt Ireland’s ability to borrow internationally, while opponents say the pact’s limits on deficits and debt could prolong Ireland’s slump.

headline.seo: Ireland Faces Battle Over Europe Stability Treaty
headline.main: European Financial Treaty Faces Skeptical Irish Voters in Tough Referendum Fight
headline.print_headline: European Financial Treaty Faces Skeptical Irish Voters in Tough Referendum Fight
